The measure comes into force next Monday, according to an order from Sam Hou Fai, published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. With a degree in Commerce (Accounting) from Monash University in Australia and a master's degree in Public Administration taught by Peking University and the Chinese Academy of Governance, Chan has been part of the AMCM staff since August 2001, although with a break between 2006 and 2009, when she worked in the Financial Information Office. After returning to AMCM, the new member performed the functions of technician, deputy director and director of the Insurance Supervision Department. DSSCU | Chan Hoi Ieng appointed deputy director Raymond Tam appointed Chan Hoi Ieng, one of his office advisors, as deputy director of the Land and Urban Construction Services Directorate (DSSCU). The appointment was revealed yesterday through the Official Bulletin. Chan Hoi Ieng has a degree in Engineering from Tsinghua University and a Master's degree in Public Administration from Peking University. At a professional level, she was a senior technician between December 1999 and November 2016 at the then Institute for Civic and Municipal Affairs. Between 2016 and 2022, she performed the same type of functions in the Customs Services, until December of last year, when she was promoted to advisor. Also in December last year, she was appointed advisor to the Office of the Secretary for Transport and Public Works. She is now chosen as deputy director of DSSCU.

item.title: What direction for Macau in 2026?
item.description: Only people from abroad will be surprised by the announcement of the list of seven deputies appointed by the Chief Executive to the 8th legislature of the Legislative Assembly. As one commentator highlighted, the personnel change is part of a “chess game”, aimed at further improving the constitutional structure with a predominance of the executive branch, under the principle of “One Country, Two Systems”, and at strengthening the functions of the administrative, legislative and judicial bodies, as well as deepening their constructive interaction. Given the effectiveness of the consultative policy that has long been in force in Macau, the chance of Cheong Weng Chon (appointed by the Chief Executive to be a deputy of the Legislative Assembly) being elected President or Vice-President of the 8th legislature of the Legislative Assembly on October 16th, in the first session of the Plenary, is very high. It is difficult to imagine how Cheong, who was Secretary for Administration and Justice, could avoid embarrassing situations in the upcoming sectoral debates on the Lines of Government Action, especially when they focus on the area of ​​administration and justice, if he simply limited himself to being a deputy. If you are elected President of the Assembly, embarrassing situations can be avoided. The three former Chief Executives of Macau, Ho Hau Wah, Chui Sai On and Ho Iat Seng, were all part of the Legislative Assembly. Ho Iat Seng, with his experience as President of the Assembly, understood very well the type of problems generated in administrative departments. After taking office as Chief Executive, Ho actually carried out in-depth work to optimize the efficiency of the administrative structure. After Macau's return to Chinese sovereignty, Cheong Weng Chon was Director of the Justice Affairs Bureau, Commissioner against Corruption, Secretary for Administration and Justice and Head of the Executive Committee of the Guangdong-Macao In-depth Cooperation Zone in Hengqin, so he is well versed in administrative matters. His frequent interactions with the Legislative Assembly during the law-making process allowed him to gain a good understanding of the capabilities and performance of deputies. If Cheong leads the 8th term of the Legislative Assembly, he will undoubtedly set a precedent for the full realization of the predominance of the executive branch under the principle of “One Country, Two Systems”. Macau, a small city with about 700,000 inhabitants and an area of ​​33.3 square kilometers, was entrusted with the task of transforming the In-depth Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau on Hengqin Island, into the new trade center of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area and the new platform for China's opening up to the outside world. As long as annual gaming revenue can remain at MOP240 billion, the SAR Government can make ends meet and provide for the basic needs of Macau residents. The problems facing public servants and small and medium-sized businesses can be resolved. A focus is needed on creating an environment that promotes business in public spaces, developing more employment opportunities for residents and investing in economic construction. The direction Macau will take in 2026 will be influenced by changes in neighboring areas. Barring unforeseen circumstances, Sanae Takaichi, who follows in the footsteps of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, will be the first woman to hold that position and will be elected at an extraordinary session of the Japanese Diet called for October 15. News indicates that US President Donald Trump will visit Japan between October 27th and 29th to meet with the Emperor and the new Prime Minister. Furthermore, the fourth plenary session of the 20th. Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) will take place in Beijing from October 20th to 23rd. This chain of interactions, which was certainly not planned, suggests the inerception of a powerful hand. At the reception commemorating the 80th anniversary of China's victory in the War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression, President Xi Jinping stated that China is a force for world peace. If this strength comes into play, Macau can still sail smoothly into 2026.

item.title: In Memoriam by Chef António Coelho
item.description: “I love Portuguese food. I love the traditional and authentic cuisine. It’s the one I learned in Portugal. For me, that’s very important because I prefer the traditional things.” Chef António Neves Coelho The guardian of Portuguese-Macanese cuisine and dear friend, Chef António das Neves Coelho, left us on October 12, 2025, at Hospital Conde de São Januário. Major figure of Portuguese gastronomy in Macau, mentor to generations, defender of culinary authenticity and symbol of institutional resilience. His departure represents an irreparable loss for the gastronomic culture of the Macao SAR and for the emotional memory of all who shared his table, kitchen and dreams with him. Chef António grew up amidst the aromas of olive oil, garlic and red wine. From an early age, he revealed a rare vocation for cooking, not just as a technique, but as a cultural narrative. His training took place in emblematic houses of Portuguese gastronomy, where he learned to respect the ingredients, times and affections that make up the culinary tradition. His international career took him to three continents and, finally, to Macau, where he completed his military service and found his true stage. From 1997 onwards, he established himself as Executive Chef and operations manager in reference spaces, becoming one of the main ambassadors of Portuguese and Macanese cuisine. Macau was not only his professional destination but his spiritual home. António understood that Macanese cuisine is not just a fusion of flavors, but also of stories. With sensitivity and rigor, he became a defender of the preservation of traditional recipes, the valorization of local ingredients and the formation of multicultural teams with a spirit of mission. He founded his own brand, where he worked as culinary director and general manager for more than a decade at António Restaurante, receiving 12 Michelin recommendations, among others. His leadership was marked by a rare combination of technical demands, human empathy and strategic vision. His cuisine was made of olive oil and affection, of technique and tenderness, of rigor and poetry. Its contribution was recognized by two highly prestigious distinctions such as the Medal of Tourist Merit, awarded by the Government of the Macao SAR, in recognition of its role in the development of the hospitality sector and local gastronomic culture and the Medal of Merit of Portuguese Communities, awarded by the Government of Portugal, for its action as a cultural bridge between continents and for the promotion of Portuguese identity abroad. These honors were not just trophies but testimonies of his dedication to the public cause, culture and excellence. In 2024, Chef António took on the leadership of a new gastronomic project at Angela Café & Lounge at Lisboeta Macau. There, he created a menu that celebrated the Portuguese and Macanese essence, with dishes such as codfish à lagareiro, seafood rice and desserts with a conventual touch. The space has become a meeting point between tradition and modernity, between tourists and locals, between memory and the future. His team, formed and inspired by him, continues to represent the pillars of his vision with dedication, creativity and commitment to excellence. Chef António's death represents a human and institutional loss of great significance. But his legacy remains alive in the memory of the customers who tasted his dishes; in the training of professionals who learned from him; in the institutional identity of the spaces he helped to build and in the gastronomic culture of Macau and the Portuguese diaspora His work does not end with his departure but continues in each preserved recipe, in each technical gesture transmitted and in each ethical value defended. More than a Chef, António was the guardian of the Portuguese-Macanese gastronomic soul. His life was a bridge between continents, flavors and generations. His cuisine was made of memory and innovation, of technique and tenderness, of rigor and poetry. May his memory continue to live on in every dish served, in every story told and in every young professional who dares to dream of a cuisine that respects the past and transforms the present. Before his departure, Chef António left his legatee a precious set of recipes that are not mere technical records, but authentic trophies of Portuguese cuisine, honed over decades of practice, reflection and passion. This legacy is not just a gastronomic collection but a cultural heritage, a letter of intent and a mission to fulfill. Each recipe represents a chapter of your life, a shared memory, a silent tribute to the roots that formed you. These are dishes that carry the flavor of childhood, the rigor of classical training, the boldness of reinvention and the tenderness of maturity. These are formulas that are not limited to ingredients and quantities as they contain gestures, silences, waiting times, and above all, intention. The legatee, chosen with discernment and trust, did not just receive a recipe book. He received a culinary testament, a map of values ​​and institutional responsibility. It will now be up to you to execute, preserve and reinterpret these creations with fidelity and courage, keeping the flame of authenticity alive without falling into the rigidity of repetition. In the Portuguese tradition, the transmission of recipes is an act of intimacy and respect. It's not just about teaching but about trust. Chef António understood this deeply. For this reason, the recipes he left were not disseminated en masse, nor transformed into a commercial product. They were given to those who knew how to understand his spirit, to those who shared his daily kitchen with him and to those who demonstrated technical ability and human sensitivity. These recipes include classic dishes and conventual desserts reinterpreted with local ingredients. But they also include new creations, designed for special occasions, themed menus and cultural tributes. These are dishes that never reached the public, but that can now be revealed with the care they deserve. Executing these recipes is not just reproducing flavors but embodying a philosophy. The legatee will have to maintain a balance between fidelity and evolution, technique and emotion, tradition and contemporaneity. You will have to respect the times, the gestures, the silences that Chef António taught. You will have to understand that each dish is also a message, a memory and an affirmation of identity. More than cooking, it will have to cure in a museological and emotional sense. Curate the legacy, protect it from trivialization and present it with dignity. You will have to train others, transmit the values ​​you received, ensure that the legacy does not disappear over time, but multiplies with meaning. This work is not just gastronomic but curatorial, educational and diplomatic. It is a way of affirming that cuisine is also culture, that the dish is also a document and that the flavor is also memory. The recipes left by Chef António are seeds. It is now up to the legatee and the institution involved to cultivate them with respect, water them with knowledge and make them flourish with creativity. Each time one of these recipes is served, it will be as if Chef António were present not as a shadow, but as a light. This legacy is a rare gift. And like any precious gift, it requires care, time and love. May it be honored with the same generosity with which it was conceived. May it be shared with the same elegance with which it was lived. May it be perpetuated with the same passion with which it was created. Because in the kitchen, as in life, what remains is not what is repeated, it is what is respected.

item.title: Sex and emotions
item.description: Sex can awaken a range of emotions. From positive to negative — including neutral — emotions often emerge in a haphazard way, without us being able to give them immediate meaning. There are those who even experience emotional combinations that place side by side emotions that at first glance would be opposites: pleasure and shame. These responses, however, are culturally shaped. Sex, deep down, is a microcosm of human emotional life, where body, culture and identity intersect. Attachment theory, often described as the theory of love, shows how the search for security, or its absence, shapes our emotional response in relationships with others. The body has hormonal mechanisms associated with pleasure, which make us feel safe, but also others that can perpetuate our sense of insecurity. The way emotional responses are created depends largely on context and our past experiences. Therefore, emotions often become a lens through which we look at the world. The psychology of emotions has crossed two important lineages to understand these mechanisms. One of them is medicine, where emotion results from physiological construction and regulation. The other comes from anthropology, which has explored how culture shapes our emotional responses. For example, intercultural studies have shown that in more individualistic societies, where anger is a form of expression of breaking relationships with others – in an attempt to impose limits – the physiological response is stronger than in collectivist societies. In societies where the group configuration has a more determining weight on the sense of self, anger is just an indicator that there is disharmony in the group relationship, and the physiological response and inflammation levels are lower. Anger is not perceived as a radical break from the collective, and therefore the experience of anger is, in some way, more sustained. This cultural dimension becomes even more evident when we analyze the way in which various gender expressions construct their emotional worlds. Although popular culture tells us that there are differences between 'men' and 'women', the truth is that there is much more variability within each group than between them, which makes it difficult to justify a clear distinction. This division is culturally fueled and manifests itself in everyday gestures. Studies show that when women arrive at an emergency room with palpitations, they are more quickly diagnosed with anxiety than with a heart attack. The same does not happen with men, from whom a lesser emotional manifestation is expected, and therefore symptoms such as palpitations are rarely confused with anxiety. Thus, it becomes almost expected for women to express excessive emotions and for men to repress them — which distorts our notion of what is ‘normal’ or ‘deviant’. It is worth bringing here an essential distinction in the theory of emotions: there are primary emotions, which are more immediate and more faithful to our internal states, and secondary emotions, which are in some way a complexification of the first, fed by beliefs, narratives and cultures. If at a certain moment I feel angry, and if my life experience has taught me that anger is an inappropriate emotion, other emotions quickly take over, such as shame or guilt. All of this is relevant to better understanding emotions during sex. In the reductive binarism of custom, generalist beliefs persist that impose performance pressure on men and feelings of guilt on women — dynamics that are also reflected in same-sex relationships. When we realize that the emotions that emerge do not correspond to what culture defines as 'normal', we begin to monitor and censor what we feel. Without a deep understanding of emotions, the body and the context in which they are inserted, we end up complicating our lives. For example, the emotions that follow sex vary as much as the experiences themselves. Some feel a peaceful well-being, a feeling of closeness and tenderness — the so-called afterglow. Others experience the opposite: a certain melancholy or emptiness known as post-sex dysphoria. These emotional states seem to depend less on the physical act and more on the meaning that each person attributes to it — connection, validation, curiosity or loneliness. Emotions are closely linked to the meanings we attribute to things. It is the deeper conversations about emotions that free us from the artificial limits that prevent full emotional honesty. Only by understanding these processes — which translate social contexts and cultural narratives into physiological and emotional responses that the body carries — can we better understand sex, its pleasures and its difficulties. And if we treat sex as a conversation between bodies and emotions — perhaps we can listen to ourselves, and others, with more presence and empathy.

item.title: The Pat Sin Leng Fire
item.description:
On the 10th, it became known through the Hong Kong media that an eight-year-old child had made three calls to the police claiming that there was a fire in Pat Sin Leng, Tai Po, and that 25 teachers and students were trapped on the mountain. After the alert, the police, together with the Agriculture and Fisheries department and the Fire Department, arrived at the scene and verified that there was no fire. The boy was later located, admitted that he had lied and received a verbal warning. Although this incident is nothing more than a trivial matter, unlikely to arouse public concern, it does not fail to awaken painful memories. The phrase “there is a fire in Pat Sin Leng” evokes memories of the accident that occurred 30 years ago. On February 10, 1996, four teachers from Fung Yiu King Memorial School in Hong Kong accompanied a group of Year 7 and 8 students on a hike in Pat Sin Leng. It is suspected that the fire started because someone threw a burning cigarette into the bush. The fire spread across the mountain and the way down was blocked, forcing everyone to climb. Due to the difficulties of the terrain, they had to climb the “Maliu Cliff” rock to escape. Two teachers stayed behind to help the students climb the cliff. Thirty-two managed to return to the starting point to seek help. After helping most of the young people, the two teachers were unable to climb the cliff and died in the fire along with two students. In this incident, two teachers and three students died and thirteen were injured. Another hiker, who had helped rescue some of the fire victims, later self-imposed, possibly due to suffering from post-traumatic stress. In 1996, the Court ruled that the cause of the accident was “undoubtedly human”, but it was not clear whether it was due to a poorly extinguished cigarette or a fire that may have been lit as a joke. To honor the sacrifice of the two teachers, the Hong Kong Government had a pavilion erected in their memory in Pat Sin Leng, called “Spring Breeze Pavilion,” which means “good teachers” in Chinese.” Inside the pavilion, bilingual inscriptions in Chinese and English recount the entire incident. Two Buddhist pine trees were planted in front of the pavilion, in honor of the two teachers. A plaque commemorating the Spring Breeze Pavilion is placed at the entrance to Fung Yiu King Memorial School. Memorial services are held annually to share the events with students. The Fung Yiu King Memorial School has partnered with the Chinese University of Hong Kong to create a scholarship in memory of the two teachers named after them. The boy's lie undoubtedly rekindled painful memories. These memories should disappear over time instead of remaining in people's memories. Let's hope the lies end here and never resurface. May the painful memories be carried away by the wind. The spirit of the two teachers who sacrificed themselves for others lives on in Hong Kong society and is celebrated by all. We need to ask: why do we celebrate altruism? Is it because we only have one life, so when someone sacrifices themselves for others they deserve respect? The answer is not that simple. We only have one life and after death there is nothing more. The reason for celebrating self-sacrifice for the benefit of others is a way of celebrating the fact that someone capable of this act is completely devoid of selfishness, someone who only wants the good of others. This is a pure manifestation of love for humanity. If those who have been saved can continue to pass on this love, selfishness will decrease and genuine friendship will increase. With this kind of unifying love, there will naturally be no hostility, because love brings together. In this sense, love can promote a more peaceful and harmonious society and everyone will be happy. In today's complex society, human hearts are unpredictable. Even if we want to bring our love to others, it is not always accepted. This is undoubtedly a harsh reality. The students who were injured in Pat Sin Leng, and who faced many trials, must certainly have left those bad times behind, strived to live their lives and start a new chapter, but at the same time they must have remembered the two teachers who saved them. Their ability to sacrifice on behalf of students is not only worthy of imitation, but it is a lesson that must be learned and passed on. Only love can unite us all in a selfless way. It has been thirty years since the Pat Sin Leng fire, but time will not fade the memory of the sincere and selfless love that these two teachers gave to their students. Through today's news, let us once again silently pay tribute to them. May they live happily in the Afterlife, and may the love they had for their students continue to be transmitted forever.
Legal Consultant of the Association for the Promotion of Jazz in Macau Associate Professor at the Faculty of Management Sciences of the Macau Polytechnic University Email: cbchan@mpu.edu.mo

item.title: Photography | Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro distinguished at Budapest International Photo
item.description: Portuguese photojournalist Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro, based in Macau for over 15 years, was awarded the Gold award in the Editorial/Political category of the prestigious Budapest International Foto Awards (BIFA), with a photo report on the visit of the President of the People's Republic of China, Xi Jinping, to Macau, during the celebrations of the 25th anniversary of the MSAR. Created for Agência Lusa, the photographic series documents key moments of the presidential visit, with images that capture the solemn atmosphere of the official ceremonies and the political symbolism of the occasion. "I am very happy with this achievement. This photographic series documents key moments of President Xi Jinping's visit to Macau to mark the 25th anniversary of the MSAR. With images of the President and the authorities who accompanied him, the report portrays the formal atmosphere of the celebrations, highlighting the political weight of the visit", said the photojournalist, former editor of HM, quoted in a statement. The photographs, marked by rigorous framing and close observation, reveal the choreography of State protocol, the symbolism of unity and the persistent ties between Macau and mainland China at this historical moment. “Through careful compositions and a close look, I sought to reflect the ceremonial staging and the importance of the moment for Macau and its relationship with Beijing.” The award reinforces the international recognition of press photography produced in Macau and highlights the fundamental role of photojournalism in documenting political events of global importance, highlights the same note.

item.title: IPOR | Vila Franca de Xira wine tasting takes place today
item.description: The session open to the public of the initiative “The Reinvention of the Real” — Art and Wines in Dialogue at the Macau International Art Biennial 2025” takes place today, starting at 6:30 pm, at the Instituto Português do Oriente (IPOR) premises. The event will be attended by winemaker João Passarinho, viticulture and oenology technician at Quinta Municipal da Subserra, who will lead the tastings and comment on the selected wines, after a first session held yesterday exclusively for professionals in the sector. The event is part of “Art Macau – Macau International Art Biennial 2025”, as part of the preliminary inauguration of the Vila Franca de Xira City Pavilion, which will be on display at the Tap Seac Gallery until 16 November. According to a note from IPOR, these meetings “propose a reflection on the limits of perception and representation, bringing together artists, curators and the public around practices that challenge reality”, and these sessions include tastings of “Encostas de Xira” wines, produced by the municipality itself. Quinta Municipal da Subserra, founded in the 19th century. XVII, is ancestrally linked to agricultural activity. It is part of the Palace and Chapel of S. José, with 17th century tiles and a main altar canvas by the famous painter Bento Coelho da Silveira. The Quinta is owned by the municipality of Vila Franca de Xira and produces its own wine, “Encostas de Xira”. These wines are made from varieties such as Syrah or Touriga Nacional in the Reds and Arinto or Moscatel in the Whites, selected grapes, grown in clay-limestone soils, under the name IGP-Lisboa, describes a note from IPOR.

item.title: Grand Prix | New work launched with the estate of Victor Hugo Lemos
item.description: After the edition of “Macau Grand Prize – Personal Collection of Victor H. de Lemos, 1954-1978, Volume I (1954-1966)”, in 2023, the second edition of this collection by Victor Hugo Lemos is almost reaching the public. The second volume of the book written by his son, Carlos Lemos, is presented at APOMAC on November 6 The Macau public will have access to the continued preservation of Victor Hugo de Lemos' estate on the Macau Grand Prix thanks to the launch of a second volume of a book already published in 2023 by his son, Carlos Lemos. The first volume, entitled “Macau Grand Prize – Personal Collection of Victor H. de Lemos, 1954-1978, Volume I (1954-1966)”, was published with the support of the Association of Retirees, Retirees and Pensioners of Macau (APOMAC), and the same is happening now. The second volume of the work, dedicated to the years 1967 to 1978, and which is described as the “complete history of the Macau Grand Prix”, will be launched on November 6th, starting at 3pm, at APOMAC headquarters. Victor Hugo Lemos, now deceased, was “the greatest enthusiast of motor sport” and of this competition in particular, having, “during successive years, closely followed the races on the Guia circuit, having managed to gather a vast collection of photographs, written press clippings, circuit access tickets and posters”. There is still no shortage of records capable of attracting the biggest Grand Prix fans, namely “autographs from great drivers such as Sir Stirling Moss, Sir Jack Brabham, Juan Manuel Fangio, Sir Jackie Stewart, among others”. According to a note from APOMAC, this second edition is “a relic for all motor sport lovers, particularly those who participated in the event and for collectors of iconographic records”. Booty of respect In 2023, Carlos Lemos, resident in Canada and member of the Macau community, declared that, by releasing the first volume of the book, he fulfilled “his dream of releasing a book about the first twenty-five years of the Macau Grand Prix”. It is a book “different from all other books previously released” containing 256 pages and more than 250 photographs. The first volume shared records from the beginning of the competition, in 1954, until 1978. This is the last edition of the work relating to the Macanese's estate. At the time of the first launch, Jorge Fão even suggested that the Grand Prix Museum acquire Victor Lemos's estate for display. The work launched on November 6th costs 400 patacas, but on the day of presentation it will be on sale for 350 patacas, with the proceeds going to “two social organizations”.

item.title: FRC | Debate on criminal issues in the PLP takes place today
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) presents today, starting at 6:30 pm, a debate on “Paradigmatic Penal Issues in Portuguese-Speaking Countries”, which includes four thematic lectures. This is an initiative that is part of the “Cycle of Reflections at Dusk”, moderated by Leonor Esteves, from Universidade Lusíada do Porto. Today, the sessions “Nullum crimen sine lege and article 7 (Custom) of the Constitution of the Republic of Angola” are taking place, led by professor Luzia Bebiana de Almeida Sebastião, from the Faculty of Law of the Agostinho Neto University, Angola; and the conversation “Criminal Law and Democracy: the recent experience of the Brazilian case” by professor Fernando Andrade Fernandes, from the Department of Public Law of the Faculty of Human and Social Sciences of the Universidade Estadual Paulista, UNESP, Brazil. Another session is entitled “The material legitimacy of the crime of association in Mozambican law” by legal advisor and professor Elysa Vieira, from the Constitutional Council and Eduardo Mondlane University, Mozambique; and also the “Inviolability of communications and seizure of electronic mail” by professor Maria João Antunes, from the Faculty of Law of the University of Coimbra. The presence in the territory of this group of guest speakers is part of the 15th International Law Conference, this year dedicated to “Macau Legal Reforms in the Global Context: Studies on the Penal Code and the Macau Criminal Procedure Code”, organized by the Legal Studies Center of the Faculty of Law of the University of Macau, which takes place today and tomorrow and has the support of the FRC.

item.title: Fire leads to two hospitalizations and evacuation of 50 people
item.description: Two people had to be admitted to Kiang Wu Hospital, after a fire broke out on Wednesday night, in the Si Keng Building, on Rua da Alegria. In addition to the injured, there was also a need to remove 50 residents from the building, according to information released yesterday by the newspaper Ou Mun. Those hospitalized are two residents aged around 60, one male and one female, who reportedly showed signs of being unwell after inhaling smoke from the fire. Despite their indisposition, their clinical situation was considered stable. The remaining residents also managed to leave the building by their own means and did not present any type of discomfort or injuries. The flames began to break out at around 11:44 pm, when authorities were alerted to the situation. The arrival at the scene of both the Fire Department (CB) and the Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) took place minutes later, at a time when several of the building's inhabitants were already on the street. At the scene, firefighters had to climb to the third floor, where the fire originated. Fighting the flames took a few minutes. Traces indicate that the flames broke out next to a vase with flowers, and then reached the living room of the apartment on the third floor. During the fight against the fire, authorities closed Rua da Alegria and Estrada do Repouso to traffic for several minutes. Firefighters used water to fight the fire, which resulted in a burned area measuring 2.5 meters long and 1 meter wide. From the origins According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the CB suspects that the flames originated from a short circuit in a washing machine, positioned next to the vase with flowers. In addition to the burned area, the washing machine, a purifier, an air conditioner and other appliances and goods were also destroyed. According to the most recent data, in the first six months of the year, the CB was called to intervene in 406 fires. Among these, firefighters had to use hoses to extinguish the flames on 85 occasions. In the remaining 321 fires, the flames were extinguished without using a hose. Official information also revealed that 78 of the 406 fires originated from burnt food.

item.title: Hengqin | Portuguese restaurant opens across the border
item.description: It’s called “Vivo” and it’s a Mediterranean cuisine restaurant that opens its doors tomorrow in Hengqin. João Maria Pegado, one of the project's partners and previously linked to sport, is now investing in the restaurant sector and has high expectations given the tourist demand on the island. A Mediterranean cuisine restaurant officially opens tomorrow in Hengqin. Located in the Huafa shopping center, the Vivo restaurant is a project by two Portuguese people who saw an opportunity to bring two geographies closer together – China and southern Europe. It's not about fusion cuisine. Still, several traditions coexist in this restaurant: Portuguese, Spanish and Italian cuisine, prepared by a chef from Shanghai with Chinese raw materials. “We are in China, we want to invest in fresh Chinese products”, one of the partners, João Maria Pegado, tells Lusa. So much so that, for now, there is no traditional octopus à lagareiro on the menu. You have to continue browsing local markets until you find the ideal product, explains Pegado. "We could go to Macau to get frozen octopus, but our main objective was to work with fresh products in China. In terms of cost, it makes it much more profitable, but we also want to take advantage and create this fusion between Chinese products and Portuguese dishes", he says. Vivo has been in ‘soft opening’ mode since July 18th. And João Maria Pegado does not complain about the journey he has taken so far, despite the difficulty of the language. More and more To Lusa, Pegado says he will soon compete for support from the Macau Government, at a time when authorities are encouraging investment in the Macau-Guangdong Deep Cooperation Zone, in Hengqin. And this region attracts more and more visitors to Macau, says the investor. In this area managed by both sides of the border, the movement of drivers from Macau is now permitted, for example, upon request for a license, recalls Pegado. But there are other attractions: gasoline is cheaper – “the cars in Macau come to fill up at the weekend, we [Portuguese] are like in Badajoz” – supermarkets are more affordable, more space and more green areas. "An open space where you can relax without being in the middle of the city. That's the big reason why people leave Macau for Hengqin on the weekend and sometimes even during the week, at lunchtime", he reflects. Hengqin also seems to be a more economical option for Chinese people visiting Macau, where, according to data for August, the average price of a hotel room is 1,461 patacas. "Hengqin has increasingly become a point of concentration, of sleeping, used by many visitors. Many of the buildings that were built as offices, the Government gave licenses (…) to build Airbnb-style hotels [local accommodation]", he said. Hong Kong and Macau are, for now, the origin of the majority of the restaurant's visitors, but João Maria Pegado also hopes to reach more consumers from the interior of China. “There are still few people who know what Mediterranean [the concept] means”, he highlights, noting, however, that, for many of those who have visited Vivo, black paella has been a recurring choice. This dish is joined by other specialties of the house, such as fisherman's rice, guilloche prawns or barbecue chicken, says Pegado, who left a career linked to sport to dedicate himself to the restaurant business. “It’s special”, he admits. “I felt that there was a lack of a Western food restaurant, and that it could be successful in that area (…). I have lived in Hengqin for three years and it is a place that I really appreciate, it allows me to be close to Macau, the city where I grew up and with which I feel identified”, he concludes.

item.title: Macau | IMF cuts growth forecast to 2.6 percent
item.description: For the second time this year, the IMF revised growth forecasts for Macau's economy. In April, the initial forecast of 7.3 percent was cut to 3.6. Now it is believed that economic expansion will not even reach 3.0 percent The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects Macau's economy to grow 2.6 percent throughout this year. The new estimate released yesterday, and cited by the Macau News Agency, means a downward revision of the previous forecast, which pointed to an annual expansion of 3.6 percent. In the first half of the year, the territory showed annual growth of 2.8 percent, however, the IMF believes that the pace has been slowing down since July. The data used by the IMF to make the estimate assumes that inflation throughout this year should remain at 0.5 percent, a reduction from the previous forecast of 0.9 percent. The downward revision of estimates is not limited to forecasts for this year. Next year's annual increase was also revised downwards to 2.8 percent. The IMF's previous estimate, from April, predicted an expansion of 3.5 percent. Last year Macau's economy grew 8.8 percent. In the first ten months of the year, gross revenue from gambling, Macau's main economic activity, showed an annual growth of 7.1 percent, to 181.34 billion patacas, compared to 169.35 billion patacas. However, revenues during Golden Week, at the beginning of October, were below expectations. The IMF's expectations fall short of the forecasts of the Macau Economic Association, led by deputy Joey Lao, which points to annual growth of 4.5 percent. Opposite trends The IMF's downward revision of Macau's expansion estimates contrasts with the scenario in Hong Kong and the interior. In the HKSAR, an increase is expected throughout this year that is lower than that recorded in the Macao SAR. However, the most recent estimate points to an increase of 2.4 percent, when an expansion of 1.5 percent was previously expected. In the Interior, estimates are also now more optimistic. In April, the economy was expected to grow 4 percent, which has now been revised to 4.8 percent, above the levels of Macau and Hong Kong. This is the second time this year that estimates for Macau's economy have been revised downwards by the IMF. Before the start of the year, economic expansion of around 7.3 percent was expected. However, in April, the value was cut to 3.6 percent. At the time, Macau was affected, like world trade, by the impact of the tariff policy adopted in the United States.

item.title: Tourism | Andy Wu calls for greater disclosure of intangible heritage
item.description: Andy Wu, president of the Macau Tourism Industry Association, argues that intangible cultural heritage should be more widely publicized to tourists, at a time when the Cultural Institute has just announced 12 new classifications, namely the making of cream puffs and traditional almond cookies, traditional Chinese wedding cakes and the making of jook-sing dough. According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the association leader understands that cultural tourism offers can include intangible cultural heritage, providing extraordinary experiences to tourists, namely the holding of custard tart and almond biscuit workshops, among others. This type of event would be organized between the sector, education linked to tourism and personalities from society, so that visitors would have more information about the production process. Andy Wu hopes that the Government will provide more support as he understands that these initiatives can help to overcome the lack of spaces for tourists to have these types of experiences. Few stores still make traditional Chinese wedding cakes.

item.title: Taiwan | Residents seduced people into scams
item.description:
This Monday, six residents were arrested on suspicion of being linked to a criminal group in Taiwan associated with fraud, and who had recruited nine residents to extort money from victims. The investigation began in September last year, and the Judicial Police is still investigating the amounts involved
This Monday, the Judiciary Police arrested six Macau residents allegedly involved with a Taiwanese criminal group associated with fraud. According to the Ou Mun newspaper, the case began when the Judiciary Police (PJ) began an investigation after receiving requests for help from family members of nine missing Macau residents. Authorities later realized that these nine residents had been detained by Taiwan police and sentenced to prison terms of three to eight months for committing the crime of fraud. The role of these residents was to receive and deliver the extorted money to fraud victims, with four of these residents later returning to Macau after serving their sentence. It is estimated that the nine residents received thousands to tens of thousands of renminbi in payment for these roles. The Macau PJ then realized that the nine residents tried in Taiwan had been recruited by the six arrested on Monday, with promises of high salaries to carry out illegal activities in the former Formosa. Amounts to be calculated The PJ also realized that two of the six detainees are the main perpetrators of the criminal group in Taiwan, having received illegal payments of 1 to 3 percent for each amount of fraud extorted by the nine residents detained in Taiwan. However, the PJ said it needed to investigate the specific amounts received by these two main perpetrators of the crime, as well as the illegal remuneration received by the other suspects. The case was forwarded to the Public Prosecutor's Office for further investigation, as there are suspicions of the crime of criminal association.

item.title: Economy | Stability forecast in the fourth quarter
item.description: The Macau Economic Association has just released the latest Prosperity Index, which forecasts a stable economy until December. According to a statement from the association, despite considering the performances of the gaming and tourism sectors during Golden Week to be excellent, there are economic areas that still perform weaker, such as consumption, credit and confidence in local investments. For this reason, the association assigned, on a scale of 0 to 10, 6.2 points, 6 points and 6.1 points, respectively, for the months of October, November and December with regard to the economic situation, which means a level of stability. Furthermore, the association highlighted that data related to tourism and gaming in the third quarter were strong, predicting positive growth in Gross Domestic Product of around 7 percent in the third quarter. Foreign Exchange Reserves | Monthly increase of 1.6% In September, the Macao SAR's foreign exchange reserves increased by 1.6 percent to 239.2 billion patacas, compared to the adjusted amounts in August. The data was released yesterday by the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM), through a press release. In August, foreign exchange reserves reached 235.4 billion patacas. The effective exchange rate of the pataca, weighted by its trade shares, was 100.8 in September 2025, which represented a drop of 0.06 points in monthly terms and an annual reduction of 1.60 points. In view of this variation, AMCM reported that globally “the pataca fell against the currencies of Macau’s main trading partners”.

item.title: Housing | Loans sink 34 percent
item.description: In August, the value of new housing loans approved by Macau banks registered an annual reduction of 34.8 percent, according to data released yesterday by the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM). In August this year, new housing loans represented 820.82 million patacas, whereas in August 2024 they had reached 1.26 billion patacas. When the comparison is made between August of this year and the previous month, July, the reduction was 22.2 percent, compared to the value of 1.05 billion reported by AMCM. Of the 820.82 million patacas approved in new loans, residents were responsible for 806.05 million, a reduction of 22.5 percent compared to the previous month. In relation to commercial loans for real estate activities, in August the value was 1.14 billion patacas, an annual increase, given that in August 2024 the value had been 954.23 million patacas. At the end of August 2025, the unpaid debt ratio on housing loans was 3.8 percent, an increase of 0.1 percentage points compared to July. In relation to August 2024, non-compliance decreased by 0.5 percentage points, as at that time it was 4.3 percent. The unpaid debt ratio of commercial loans for real estate activities reached 5.5 percent, an increase of 0.1 percentage points compared to July. In annual terms, non-compliance grew by 1.6 percentage points.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Men should refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish because of it, tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the land will be destroyed. pride of countries. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were limited, or if it simply lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each one. to be, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters are eight years old – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the place of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, in a different way, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: China | Large deposit with more than 40 tons of gold discovered
item.description: The Chinese province of Gansu announced the discovery of a new large gold deposit in the Qianhongquan-Heishanbeitan area, in the municipality of Yumen, with reserves estimated at more than 40 tons, state television CCTV reported yesterday. According to the provincial Department of Natural Resources, the discovery is equivalent, in volume, to two large gold mines and adds to the deposits already identified in the Beishan belt, one of the main gold hubs in the region. Gansu ranks second in China in terms of gold reserves. In recent years, the local government has intensified prospecting within the scope of the national geological exploration plan, with a greater concentration of investments in the north of the province. The exploration project in Qianhongquan received a total investment of 76.28 million yuan and made it possible to complete 30,000 cubic meters of excavations and more than 35,000 meters of drilling, according to CCTV. The work resulted in the identification of a new mineralized strip approximately 14 kilometers long and between 10 and 100 meters wide, with reserves of more than 40 tons of gold. The discovery in Gansu occurs in a context of strong appreciation of gold, whose price recently surpassed 4,000 dollars per ounce, reaching a new historic high. The precious metal has risen by more than 50 percent since the beginning of the year, driven by the weakness of the dollar, geopolitical tensions and purchases by central banks – especially from emerging economies – that seek to diversify their reserves. In recent years, the growth of the Chinese middle class and the demand for bullion as a form of protection against global macroeconomic volatility have also contributed to the increase in domestic demand for the precious metal.

item.title: North Korea | NGO calls on China to end forced deportations
item.description: The non-governmental organization (NGO) Human Rights Watch called on China to end the forcible deportations of North Koreans to its country, given the “serious risk of persecution and ill-treatment”. In a statement released on Wednesday, the NGO estimated that China has deported 406 people to North Korea since the beginning of 2024, despite Chinese authorities being aware of the “oppressive conditions” in which North Koreans live. This information is based on “Stephen Kim, the pseudonym of a person with extensive contacts in North Korea and China”, whose information Human Rights Watch “has long considered reliable”, although it points to the lack of official data available. “Chinese authorities are returning hundreds of North Koreans to a place where they know that those who return will be severely persecuted,” said the head of research at Human Rights Watch in South Korea, quoted in the note. Lina Yoon urged Beijing to “immediately allow the United Nations Refugee Agency (UNHCR) access to all people at risk of forced return to North Korea”, as well as to “stop the forced repatriation of North Koreans”.

item.title: East Timor | Joining ASEAN is fighting for peace, dialogue and development
item.description: Xanana Gusmão highlighted the importance of Timor-Leste joining the group of Asian nations in defense of peace and regional development The Prime Minister of Timor-Leste stated yesterday that the most important thing about joining the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is to add a voice to a group of countries for peace, dialogue and development. "We cannot say that we will receive all the benefits and we cannot also say that we will benefit all the ASEAN countries. We will take advantage of this membership to perhaps facilitate many areas that we still need. We are the poorest, most backward country in ASEAN", stated Xanana Gusmão. Timor-Leste will become the 11th member state of ASEAN, on the 26th, during the summit of heads of state and government of the Southeast Asian organization, which will take place in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, 14 years after submitting the application for admission. "The important thing for us is to add our voice, from Timor-Leste, to a group of countries for peace, reconciliation, dialogue and sustainable development. (…) We are not going to play a crucial role in ASEAN", highlighted Xanana Gusmão. "We don't really have the ambition [that] we will receive many benefits nor do we have the ambition to say that we are the ones who are going to guide or direct ASEAN. We are studying the way in which some countries behaved and guided their development", insisted the head of the Timorese Government. Asked by Lusa about the post-accession plan, presented on Wednesday, at the Council of Ministers meeting, by the deputy minister for ASEAN Affairs, Milena Rangel, Xanana Gusmão said that more realism is needed. “Let's study, let's see, let's be more realistic, let's look more at what we need, at what the people are asking for, rather than presenting ourselves as a country that, immediately, with that roadmap, will be anything we've dreamed of for a long time”, added the prime minister, who was speaking at the end of the weekly meeting with Timorese President José Ramos-Horta. Defined objectives The post-accession plan for the period 2026-2030 establishes, according to the statement from the Council of Ministers, the “strategic intention of transforming Timor-Leste's participation in ASEAN into concrete and measurable results, through the strengthening of institutional capacity, economic diversification and the development of human capital”. The document “highlights Timor-Leste’s active contribution to the ASEAN Vision 2045, aimed at building a resilient, innovative, dynamic and people-centered regional community”, the statement read. The note highlights that the strategic objective aims to prepare Timor-Leste to receive the rotating presidency of ASEAN in 2030. “With the rigorous implementation of this plan, Timor-Leste will no longer be just a new member but will assert itself as an active and contributing partner of ASEAN, using regional integration as a catalyst for sustainable national development and the prosperity of the Timorese people”, he adds. ASEAN was created in 1967 by Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines and aims to promote cooperation between member states to ensure peace, stability and economic, social and cultural development in the region. ASEAN also includes Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar (formerly Burma) and Vietnam.

item.title: India | Elephant population has declined by a quarter in eight years
item.description: India's wild elephant population has declined by a quarter in the past eight years, reaching almost 22,500 individuals, a government-led census reveals. According to the latest statistics from the World Wildlife Fund (WWF), fewer than 50,000 Asian elephants remain in the wild across the world, 60 percent of them on Indian soil. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has included them on its long list of threatened animal species. The study published on Tuesday by the Indian government identified a total of 22,446 elephants in India based on their DNA, compared with 29,964 counted in 2017 using another method, a decline of 25 percent. “Threats include the reduction of their natural habitat, fragmentation (of herds) and the increase in cases of conflict between elephants and humans”, can be read in the report to explain this decline. The authors emphasized the isolation or “rapid dispersion” of the herds, which they attribute, in particular, to the expansion of land dedicated to tea and coffee plantations, the construction of fences and the reduction of forest areas. The distribution of Indian elephant populations currently represents just 3.5 percent of their historical size, they estimated. “Strengthening corridors and their connections, restoring natural habitats, improving protection strategies and reducing the impact of development projects are necessary to protect” the species, the authors also recommended. The census was carried out through DNA analysis of 21,000 manure samples and a network of camera traps.

item.title: Japan | Salaries record record increase
item.description: A survey by the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare found that the increase in average wages reached a record this year, since records in this regard began to be compiled in their current form, in 1999. The survey was carried out between the months of July and August and targeted private companies with 100 or more workers. The survey received responses from 1,847 companies, or 50.7 percent of those contacted, according to NHK world. According to the findings, among companies that implemented or plan to implement salary reviews this year, the average monthly salary per worker increased by 13,601 yen, or around 90 dollars. The value rose by 1,640 yen, or around 11 dollars, compared to the same period last year and marks the third consecutive year of record salary increases. Companies linked to labor unions increased salaries by 15,229 yen, or approximately 101 dollars, while companies without union links recorded an increase of 11,980 yen, or around 79 dollars. The larger the size of the company, the greater the salary increase. Labor Ministry officials said strong wage growth reflects the effects of spring labor negotiations. Employees indicated that large companies with solid financial foundations appear to be raising wages more than small and medium-sized companies to secure workers. Ministry officials also said they will continue to closely monitor salary trends.

item.title: TSMC | Almost 40% increase in profit with AI boost
item.description: TSMC, the world's largest semiconductor manufacturer, announced yesterday an increase of almost 40 percent in net profit for the last quarter, driven by growing demand for artificial intelligence applications. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company recorded a record net profit of 452.3 billion Taiwan dollars between July and September, exceeding analysts' forecasts. The company had already indicated that revenues grew 30 percent year-on-year in the same period. In light of trade tensions between the United States and China, TSMC has invested in building factories in the USA and Japan, in a risk diversification strategy. The Taiwanese manufacturer is a reference supplier for giants such as Apple and Nvidia. “Demand for TSMC’s products remains firm,” Morningstar analysts wrote in a recent note. "Given the company's dominant position, we doubt that it will be harmed even if it faces tariffs on exports to the US. We hope that demand for artificial intelligence solutions remains resilient", they pointed out. The US Secretary of Commerce, Howard Lutnick, proposed last month that the production of 'chips' be shared equally between Taiwan and the United States - a suggestion rejected by Taipei, where the majority of world production is currently concentrated. TSMC has already committed to investments of 100 billion dollars in the USA, including the construction of new factories in the state of Arizona, in addition to the 65 billion previously announced.

item.title: China and France hold strategic dialogue with calls for greater mutual trust
item.description: China and France agreed to strengthen mutual trust and deepen bilateral cooperation, during the 27th round of the Strategic Dialogue between the two countries, the official Chinese news agency Xinhua reported yesterday. The meeting on Wednesday brought together the head of Chinese diplomacy, Wang Yi, and the French President's diplomatic advisor, Emmanuel Bonne, and focused on strengthening bilateral political and economic relations, in addition to addressing international issues such as the war in Ukraine and the situation in the Middle East. According to the same source, the meeting took place in the context of closer contacts between Beijing and the main European capitals and served to review last year's progress in Sino-French relations, highlighting the need to maintain “strategic, stable and forward-looking” cooperation. Wang Yi argued that both countries, permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, should “deepen mutual trust”, “explore new sectors of cooperation” and strengthen coordination in multilateral forums. The head of Chinese diplomacy also expressed the desire that France promote, within the European Union, a “correct perception of China” and support the “strategic autonomy” of the European bloc. Expanding At the meeting held in the Chinese city of Hangzhou (east), Emmanuel Bonne stated, according to the Chinese Foreign Ministry, that France “maintains its independent foreign policy” and reaffirmed its commitment to the principle of “one China”. Bonne expressed Paris' intention to expand economic cooperation, in the civil nuclear energy sector, in the areas of technology and energy, “in a spirit of equality and mutual benefit”, also reiterating the rejection of “confrontation between blocs or trade wars”. This was the third conversation between Wang and Bonne in the last year, following a phone call in October 2024, in which they discussed the war in Ukraine and trade tensions between China and the European Union, and a meeting in March 2025, where they both defended the need to “prevent the world from returning to the law of the jungle” and to resolve economic differences through dialogue.

item.title: Beijing defends trade and energy cooperation with Russia as legitimate
item.description: Beijing yesterday defended its energy cooperation with Moscow as “legitimate, after Washington said it expected China to suspend purchases of Russian oil, as promised by Indian Prime Minister, Narendra Modi. “China’s normal trade with countries around the world, including Russia, is legitimate and in accordance with the rules,” Chinese diplomacy spokesman Lin Jian said at a press conference.
